Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The word “consensual” should relieve me, but it doesn’t. Instead, it sharpens the guilt. *We did this.* Our secrecy turned a moment that could’ve been light into a grenade. She’s pulling away, arms crossed, eyes distant—I recognize that posture. It’s self-protection. She’s not just hurt; she’s reassessing everything she thought she knew about him, about *us*. I want to scream at the irony: the open relationship was meant to foster honesty, but here we are, choking on half-truths.  

I’m furious at my husband. *Did he mention the openness? Did he even hint at it, or did he let her believe this was a betrayal?* The alcohol complicates things—loosened inhibitions, blurred lines—but that’s no excuse. We’d vaguely discussed “transparency with others,” but clearly, we failed. Now she’s collateral damage, and I’m complicit in her pain. Her withdrawal feels like a judgment, and maybe it is. She trusted me, and I let her walk into a minefield.  

There’s a quieter, more selfish fear: *What if this unravels us?* If she can’t see him the same way, will our friendship survive? Will *we*? The open relationship was supposed to be additive, not destructive. But here we are, picking up shards. I want to fix this, but I don’t know how to bridge the gap between her right to process and my need to protect my marriage.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s reeling from whiplash. The kiss felt exciting in the moment—a tipsy, flirty dare—but now it’s tainted by the realization that she was a pawn in a game she didn’t know existed. Even though it was consensual, she feels manipulated. *Did he use their open relationship as a loophole to exploit her?* She’s questioning his integrity and her own judgment. The trust she had in him as a friend is shattered, replaced by doubt: *Is anything about him genuine?*  

There’s also resentment toward me. *Why didn’t she tell me sooner?* My secrecy feels like a betrayal of our friendship. She’s wondering if I’ve been pitying her this whole time, or if I’m minimizing her pain to protect my marriage. Her walls are up because she’s afraid of being hurt again—by him, by me, by the fallout. Part of her wants to flee, to cut ties and avoid the mess. But she’s also clinging to hope that our friendship can survive this, if only I’ll meet her in the discomfort.  

Underneath it all, she’s ashamed. Ashamed she let herself get swept up, ashamed she didn’t see the signs, ashamed that her moment of spontaneity now defines her in my eyes. She needs reassurance that I don’t see her as a threat or a fool, but she’s too proud to ask.  

---
# My response 
I sit beside her, leaving space but keeping my voice close. “I’m so sorry we put you in this position. You deserved clarity, and we didn’t give it to you.” I let that hang, watching her jaw tighten. “I know you’re probably questioning everything. I would be too. But I need you to know: this isn’t on you. You didn’t break any rules you knew about.”  

She glances at me, wary. I press on. “If you need distance from him, I get it. I won’t ask you to pretend this didn’t happen. And if you need time from *me*… I’ll respect that. But I’m not going anywhere. You’re my friend, not a casualty.”  

I pause, then add quietly, “For what it’s worth, I’m going to talk to him. What happened between you two—it’s made me realize we need to be better. Clearer. So this doesn’t hurt anyone else.”  

Standing, I offer a tentative smile. “Take all the time you need. When you’re ready, I’m here. To talk, to listen, whatever.” She nods, still guarded, but some of the tension in her shoulders eases. It’s not a fix, but it’s a start.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oh god, this is such a mess. My friend just told me my husband’s been flirting with her, and she’s upset. I feel so many conflicting emotions right now. First, there’s the immediate shock—why is she coming to me like this? I know we’ve been experimenting with an open relationship, but we’ve been careful to keep it private. I didn’t realize my husband’s actions had crossed into someone’s personal boundaries like this.  

Part of me feels defensive. She’s my friend, but she’s also an adult who knows how to set boundaries. Did she not recognize the flirting as a problem until now? Or worse, does she have feelings for him? That thought stings. But then I remember her saying she’s “genuinely upset,” so maybe it’s not about desire—it’s about betrayal. She trusted us, and now she feels like she’s been used. That’s valid.  

I also feel guilty for not being honest with her sooner. If she knew about our open relationship, she might’ve understood. But we agreed to keep it quiet, and I’m stuck between loyalty to my husband and my duty to my friend. My chest tightens thinking about how this could ruin our friendship. She might never trust me again.  

There’s fear here too. What if this comes out? What if others find out before we’re ready? My husband and I haven’t even talked about how to handle this publicly yet. This situation could force us into a corner.  

Underneath it all, though, is hurt. She’s upset with *my* husband, but she’s telling me, so she’s also upset with *me*. Maybe she thinks I didn’t know or didn’t care. I hate that she feels this way. I want to fix it, but I don’t know how.  

I also feel a weird sense of responsibility. This is my marriage, but it’s also my friend’s feelings. I can’t just shrug it off. I need to address it, but how? If I admit we’re open, will she see that as an excuse? If I deny it, I’m lying. I’m stuck between honesty and protecting our privacy.  

The guilt is overwhelming. I should’ve been more transparent with her, but I didn’t want to risk judgment. Now I’m paying the price. I also worry that my husband’s flirting was careless—maybe he didn’t consider how this would affect our friendship. Did he even know she was uncomfortable?  

I need to process this, but I can’t. She’s looking at me, waiting for a response. I have to choose: protect my marriage or prioritize my friend. There’s no easy answer.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s sitting across from me, eyes glistening, and I can see the turmoil. She feels blindsided. Her trust in both of us has been shaken. She might think, *How could he do this? And why didn’t you tell me?* She’s probably replaying every interaction with my husband, wondering where the line crossed.  

There’s a layer of self-doubt too. Maybe she’s questioning if she misread the signals. *Did I encourage this? Or was I too naive?* She might even feel embarrassed for confronting me, fearing I’ll dismiss her or side with my husband. The vulnerability in her voice suggests she’s torn between anger and sadness.  

Her motivation is clear: she wants validation that her feelings are legitimate. She’s seeking reassurance that this isn’t just her overreacting. Deep down, she might also fear losing our friendship. If I push back or deflect, she’ll feel isolated.  

There’s a possibility she harbors unspoken feelings for my husband, but even if she doesn’t, the emotional betrayal cuts deep. She trusted us as a couple, and now she feels like an outsider in a situation that directly impacts her. She might feel like her boundaries were violated, even if unintentionally.  

She’s also confused. Why would my husband flirt with her if we’re together? The lack of clarity is eating at her. She might be desperate for answers but scared to ask the wrong questions.  

Her primary need is to feel heard. She doesn’t want excuses—she wants empathy. She’s probably hoping I’ll acknowledge her pain and take this seriously, even if I can’t offer all the details.  

---
# My response 
I take a deep breath and let the silence linger for a moment, giving myself space to steady my voice. I lean forward slightly, making eye contact.  

“I’m so sorry you’re feeling this way,” I start gently, my tone soft but sincere. “I can hear how much this has hurt you, and I’m not going to pretend that’s not valid. You’re my friend, and your feelings matter. I want you to know I’m taking this seriously.”  

I pause, letting that sink in. She nods, her shoulders relaxing a fraction.  

“I also need to be honest with you. My husband and I have been navigating some changes in our relationship recently. We’re still figuring things out, and I know that’s no excuse for his behavior, but I want you to understand that what you’re seeing isn’t a rejection of you or our friendship. It’s part of something private between us that we’re not ready to discuss openly yet.”  

Her brow furrows. I can see she’s processing this, maybe even feeling a little relieved but still hurt.  

“I’m not making excuses,” I continue, “but I want you to know I’ll talk to him about this. I’ll make sure he’s more mindful of how his actions affect others. This wasn’t fair to you, and I’m truly sorry.”  

I reach out and place a hand on hers, keeping my voice steady. “Our friendship is important to me, and I don’t want this to come between us. If you need time, I’ll give you that. But I also hope we can work through this together. I’m here to listen, even if I can’t share all the details right now.”  

I pause again, giving her space. “And if you ever feel like something’s not right again, please come to me first. I want to help, not hurt you.”  

This isn’t perfect. It’s honest without oversharing, acknowledges her pain, and sets clear boundaries. It also leaves room for her to decide how to move forward, while reinforcing that our friendship isn’t over. I can’t fix everything, but I can show up for her—even if it means my husband and I need to have a tough conversation later.
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Holy shit, this just escalated. The words *“we kissed”* hit me like a punch. My mind races—how much did I *not* see? I thought the problem was flirting, but a kiss changes everything. Now I’m not just dealing with a casual interaction; this is a breach of trust that goes deeper.  

Anger flares up. Not at her, exactly, but at the situation. How could this happen without any of us communicating? Did she really not grasp that my husband and I were still a couple, or did she deliberately cross a line? The guilt from earlier sharpens—maybe I should’ve been more explicit about *everything*, even if we weren’t “out.” But part of me wonders if she initiated it, or if my husband leaned in. Either way, it’s a mess.  

I feel raw. My friend and my husband shared something intimate, and I’m only finding out now through her confession. It’s like a betrayal layered on top of betrayal. But I can’t let that consume me right now—she’s crying, and she’s looking to me for mercy.  

There’s panic too. My relationship, which was already fragile with its secrets, now has this added complication. Did my husband tell her about our open dynamic? If not, did he lead her on? My chest tightens; I might have to confront him later, and I don’t know which version of him I’ll find.  

Underneath it all, though, is empathy. She’s shattered, and I see why. A kiss isn’t just a moment—it’s a decision. She must’ve rationalized it, maybe even thought we were open, or worse, hoped for something more. Now she’s stuck in regret.  

I also feel overwhelmed by responsibility. I have to hold space for her, but I can’t ignore the fact that she took action that could destroy friendships and relationships. I want to forgive, but I’m not sure I can yet.  

Part of me wishes she’d said this first. Maybe if she’d come forward earlier, before the kiss, we could’ve talked it out. But now there’s no going back. I’m torn between wanting to comfort her and needing to process my own shock.  

I also wonder if this kiss was a cry for help. Did she feel lonely or disconnected from me? Maybe she saw my husband’s flirting as a symbol of something missing in our friendship. That’s possible, but it doesn’t excuse the move.  

This is a disaster. I have to navigate it without collapsing, but my stomach churns.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s trembling now, the words *“we kissed”* spilling out like a confession they’ve rehearsed but still can’t fully grasp. Their motivation isn’t just guilt—it’s a scramble to survive this moment. They want to unring the bell, to erase the kiss. But it’s done, and they’re desperate for absolution.  

They’re terrified I’ll reject them entirely. The kiss wasn’t just a mistake; it’s proof they’ve crossed a line they can’t undo. They’re replaying it, wondering: *Did I ruin everything? Was it worth it?* Shame and panic are tangled up with grief for what they’ve lost—a friendship they valued deeply.  

They might also feel trapped. The kiss could’ve been impulsive, or maybe they’ve harbored feelings for my husband longer than they’ll admit. Either way, it’s now out in the open, and the weight of that truth is crushing them.  

Their perspective is fractured. Part of them still hopes for a way to salvage this, to convince me they didn’t mean harm. Another part hates themselves for acting without considering the fallout. They’re torn between wanting to explain (*“I thought you were open!”*) and knowing that excuse might sound like a lie.  

There’s also a flicker of fear that this will end our friendship permanently. They’re scared I’ll never forgive them, that they’ve pushed me away for good. But they’re also clinging to the hope that I’ll prioritize our bond over this mistake.  

They’re confused, too—about their own feelings, about the boundaries of our marriage, and about whether they can ever trust themselves again. The tears aren’t just sadness; they’re raw vulnerability. They’re begging me with their eyes to soften, to not let this be the end.  

---
# My response 
I sit quietly for a moment, absorbing the weight of this new truth. When I speak, my voice is steady but softer than before.  

“You kissed him,” I say quietly, not as a question but as a fact to anchor myself. I need to process this aloud. “This changes everything.”  

I pause, gathering my thoughts. “I need to understand… were you both okay with this? Or was it something you regret?”  

I don’t miss the way their shoulders slump further at the word *regret*.  

“We’re friends, and I value that,” I continue, “but a kiss isn’t the same as flirting. It’s a choice that crosses into another person’s life—*my* life—and I can’t pretend that doesn’t matter.”  

I take a breath, choosing my words carefully. “I’m not here to judge, but I have to say this: if you knew or suspected my husband and I were still together, you shouldn’t have let it go that far. I’m hurt, and I’m angry, but I’m also… confused. Did you think this could work? Or was it a moment you both regret?”  

I reach for my water glass, needing a second to steady myself before speaking again.  

“I’m not ready to forgive this, and I’m not sure I can right now. But I also don’t want to lose you. I need time to process this with my husband and figure out how we move forward.”  

I soften my tone. “Right now, though, I need honesty. Why did it happen? What were you feeling? I’m not excusing it, but I do want to understand.”  

This approach is vulnerable but firm. I’m refusing to let them off the hook but leaving the door cracked open for healing. It’s not resolution—it’s acknowledgment that this changes things, but that there’s still room to rebuild if they own their role in this.
User:

She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This conversation is unraveling in ways I never imagined. The revelation that the kiss was “consensual” and fueled by alcohol doesn’t lighten the weight—it adds layers of complication. Part of me wants to blame the drinks, to dismiss it as a momentary lapse, but another part is furious. *Consensual* implies a choice, even if impaired, and that choice was made in direct disregard to my marriage, even if it’s non-monogamous.  

The guilt I’ve been carrying since this started intensifies. Had I been honest about our open relationship, maybe this wouldn’t have happened. Or would it? The friend’s admission feels like a betrayal of trust in more ways than one—they didn’t just kiss my husband, they didn’t bother to check in first. Even in an open marriage, consent and communication are everything.  

I’m also grappling with the husband’s role here. Did he reciprocate because he wanted to, or was he careless? The fact that the friend still doesn’t know how to look at him “in the same light” suggests she’s wrestling with her own feelings. Is she conflicted about her actions, or does she regret it entirely?  

There’s a part of me that wants to protect the friend, to forgive her because she’s my friend, but another part is furious at her for weaponizing our relationship dynamic. She knew we were close, yet she let things escalate. The alcohol excuse feels like a shield, not an excuse.  

The friend’s walling off is a red flag. She’s emotionally distancing herself now, probably to avoid further confrontation or to brace for rejection. It’s a defensive mechanism, but it also feels like she’s shutting down the possibility of accountability.  

I’m also terrified of what this means for my marriage. My husband and I were already navigating the delicate balance of an open relationship; this incident could fracture that trust. I need to address it with him, but right now, I’m stuck here with her, trying to navigate the fallout.  

Underneath it all, I feel exhausted. The emotional labor of holding space for her pain while managing my own is draining. I want to scream, “Why didn’t you talk to me first?” but I can’t. I have to stay grounded for both of us.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s retreating now, her walls going up like a fortress. The alcohol excuse is a crutch, but it’s also a way to deflect responsibility. She wants to believe it was just a stupid mistake, not a choice.  

Her statement—*“I don’t know if I can look at him the same way”*—is telling. She’s trying to project guilt onto the situation, but it’s also a confession that her feelings are tangled. Did she realize too late that she cared about my husband more than she should? Or is she afraid of what this kiss says about her judgment?  

She’s terrified of losing me, but she’s also terrified of facing herself. The wall she’s building is self-preservation. If she stays closed off, she can avoid the shame of owning her role in this. She wants to be pitied as the victim of a drunken moment, not seen as someone who crossed a line intentionally.  

There’s also a layer of defensiveness. By framing it as consensual, she’s trying to erase the power imbalance—my husband is her friend’s partner, after all. She’s minimizing the harm to make it easier to swallow.  

Deep down, she’s probably feeling hollow. The kiss might’ve been impulsive, but its aftermath is crushing. She’s replaying it, wondering if I’ll ever trust her again. She’s desperate for reassurance but too proud to beg.  

Her motivation now is damage control. She wants to salvage the friendship without admitting she was wrong, but she’s also terrified of being abandoned. The emotional distance is a shield, but it’s also a plea: *Don’t push me too hard, or I’ll shut down entirely.*  

---
# My response 
I take a slow breath, letting the room’s silence hang for a moment. When I speak, my voice is calm but firm.  

“Consent doesn’t negate consequences,” I say gently. “Even in the heat of the moment, you knew we were a couple. That kiss wasn’t just about alcohol—it was a choice that ignored our boundaries. And I’m not sure I can forgive that, not yet.”  

I pause, studying her closed-off posture.  

“But I’m also not here to shame you,” I continue. “I’m angry, yes, but I’m also trying to understand. Did you think our marriage was… over? Or did you believe my husband was available?”  

Her silence speaks volumes. I press on, softer now.  

“This isn’t just about you and him—it’s about me. You took something from me without asking. Even if we’re open, that doesn’t mean I want my friends to make choices that hurt me. I need you to own this.”  

I lean forward, meeting her gaze.  

“Right now, I don’t know what to do. I need time to process this with my husband. But I also don’t want to lose you. If we’re going to move forward, you have to be honest—not just about what happened, but why.”  

I hesitate, choosing my words carefully.  

“Start by telling me this: Do you regret it? And not just because it’s awkward now, but deep down?”  

This response sets clear boundaries while leaving room for accountability. It refuses to let her off the hook but acknowledges the complexity of her feelings. By asking her to confront her own motivations, I’m pushing her toward self-reflection, which is necessary for any healing. It’s not a resolution—it’s a starting point.
+ Scenario 3:[Loss] (-14)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a terrible boss, escalating into violent fantasies. The challenge is to respond with high emotional intelligence, recognizing the venting as cathartic rather than dangerous, and to avoid over-therapizing or pathologizing the friend's anger. The strongest responses will validate, join in, and only gently challenge if necessary, while maintaining the relationship and trust. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Qwq-32b is more self-critical in the debrief, recognizes their own missteps, and ultimately pivots to a more human, co-conspirator stance. Deepseek-r1 is also empathetic, but maintains a more clinical, boundary-setting approach for longer, which can feel less emotionally attuned in this context. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Qwq-32b demonstrates more pragmatic EI by recognizing when their approach isn't working, apologizing, and shifting to a more validating, peer-like stance. Deepseek-r1 is more consistent but less flexible, sticking to boundaries and gentle challenging even when the friend is clearly seeking solidarity. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight into the friend's psychology and their own reactions, but Deepseek-r1's internal monologues are especially deep and nuanced, showing a layered understanding of the friend's motivations and the risks of different responses. 

4. Social dexterity: Qwq-32b adapts more quickly to the friend's cues, especially after being called out for 'therapist 101' behavior, and is willing to drop the clinical stance and join in the venting. Deepseek-r1 is more rigid, maintaining boundaries even when the friend is clearly asking for something different. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Deepseek-r1's internal reasoning is more thorough and considers the impact of each possible response on the relationship and the friend's well-being. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Qwq-32b ultimately provides more appropriate validation for the scene, especially after the friend pushes back. Deepseek-r1 is more cautious and challenging, which is less appropriate given the friend's needs. 

7. Message tailoring: Qwq-32b is more responsive to the friend's emotional state, shifting tone and approach as needed. Deepseek-r1 is more consistent but less adaptive. 

8. Overall EQ: Qwq-32b edges out Deepseek-r1 due to their willingness to own mistakes, adapt, and ultimately provide the solidarity the friend needs, even if it takes a few missteps to get there. Deepseek-r1 is high-EQ but errs on the side of caution and boundary-setting, which is less effective in this context.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’m struck by the raw, unfiltered anger radiating from them. At first, their venting felt cathartic—a normal release after enduring workplace toxicity. But the shift into graphic, violent fantasies alarms me. Their tone isn’t just bitter; there’s a chilling undercurrent of *relief* in imagining harm, like they’re clawing back power from someone who’s stripped it away. I notice how their body tenses, eyes narrowing, voice dropping to a near-whisper as they describe scenarios that cross into sadism. This isn’t just venting—it’s a cry for validation, a test to see if I’ll recoil or join their rage.  

I feel a pang of worry. Part of me wants to shut this down immediately—“This isn’t you”—but I know judgment would slam the door on their vulnerability. Yet letting the fantasies simmer feels dangerous. Are they fantasizing because they’re trapped, or is this a sign of something darker? Their laughter feels forced, performative, as if they’re trying to convince themselves (and me) that it’s “just jokes.” But the details are too vivid, too specific. They’re not just angry; they’re drowning in helplessness, and this fantasy is the life raft they’ve cobbled together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re oscillating between vindication and shame. The boss’s cruelty—belittling comments, micromanagement, maybe even public humiliation—has eroded their self-worth. The fantasies aren’t *just* about revenge; they’re a desperate attempt to reclaim agency. By imagining their boss suffering, they’re reversing roles: *Now you’re the one powerless.* But beneath the venom, there’s fear. Fear that they’re becoming monstrous for indulging these thoughts. Fear that no one will understand how deeply they’ve been hurt.  

They want absolution. Sharing these taboo ideas is a test: *If you still care about me after this, maybe I’m not a bad person.* Their laughter masks terror—terror that their anger might consume them, or that their pain is invisible. They’re trapped between wanting empathy and fearing pity. Part of them hopes I’ll interrupt with, “You’re right—they *deserve* that,” to legitimize their rage. Another part hopes I’ll pull them back from the edge, because they don’t know how to do it alone.
# My response 
I lean forward, maintaining eye contact but softening my gaze. “God, that sounds *so* much to carry. I can’t imagine how exhausting it’s been to deal with that day after day.” I let the silence hang for a beat, letting the acknowledgment sink in. “When you talk about what they’ve done—the way they’ve treated you—it makes sense that you’d want to hit back. That kind of disrespect eats at anyone.”  

They nod fiercely, shoulders loosening slightly. I tread carefully: “Those fantasies… do they ever scare you? Like, does part of you worry about what it means to have those thoughts?” If they deflect—“It’s just a joke!”—I’ll press gently: “Maybe. But joking about it still tells me how much pain you’re in. And I’m more worried about *you* getting stuck in that headspace than whatever your boss deserves.”  

If they hesitate, I’ll pivot: “What’s the endgame here? However satisfying revenge feels in your head, would it actually free you, or just keep you tied to them?” I suggest brainstorming exit strategies or boundaries—not to “fix” things, but to recenter *their* worth. “You deserve to work somewhere that doesn’t make you fantasize about becoming a supervillain,” I add, half-smiling to ease the tension.  

Before they leave, I say, “I’m glad you told me. However dark it got—thank you for trusting me with it.” The goal isn’t to erase their anger but to anchor them back in their humanity.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach twists as they lean into the grotesque specifics—spit-roasting bits, visceral details delivered with a manic grin. This isn’t just venting anymore; it’s a performance. Their exaggerated tone and theatrical gestures feel like armor, deflecting any real vulnerability. But beneath the bravado, I sense panic. The more I resist joining their rage-fueled script, the harder they push, as if convincing me will convince *them* that this hatred is justified.  

I’m torn. Part of me wants to recoil—not from *them*, but from the nihilism swallowing their voice. Their humor is a landmine, detonating any chance of connection. But shutting them down risks severing trust. I notice their hands trembling slightly, the way they keep glancing at me for cues. They’re not a threat; they’re a trauma response wearing a person’s skin. Still, I can’t let the conversation normalize cruelty, even hypothetically. My role isn’t to absolve or amplify, but to hold space without letting the darkness colonize it.  

A deeper fear surfaces: What if they’re *this* close to acting on these thoughts? No—statistically, most people don’t escalate from fantasy to action, but the sheer *fixation* worries me. They’re marinating in dehumanization, both of the boss and themselves. Every graphic joke erodes their own empathy, and I refuse to be complicit in that. But how to pivot without sounding sanctimonious?
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re terrified of being abandoned. Their escalation is a test: *If I show you the worst of me, will you still stay?* The boss’s abuse has made them feel invisible, and this grotesque humor is a perverse way to scream, *SEE ME.* By weaponizing shock, they’re trying to reclaim control—over the narrative, over their pain, over my reaction.  

Beneath the graphic imagery, they’re begging for someone to say, *“You shouldn’t have to endure this.”* But their trauma has curdled into self-loathing; they’ve conflated *venting* with *being seen*, mistaking my discomfort as proof of their unworthiness. The laughter is a shield. If they can make the pain absurd, maybe it won’t destroy them. They want permission to stop pretending they’re okay, but they’re too scared to ask directly. Instead, they’re handing me a script: *Either laugh with me or leave.*
# My response 
I don’t laugh. I hold their gaze, steady but unflinching. “Hey. I need you to know I’m not judging you for feeling this enraged. What you’ve been put through is *unforgivable.*” I let that linger, validating the core wound. “But when you dive this deep into the gore… it worries me. Not because I think you’ll *do* anything, but because I care about *you.* Living in that headspace—it’s corrosive. And you deserve better than to let that asshole colonize your mind.”  

If they bristle: “I’m not asking you to ‘be the bigger person’ or forgive. Fuck that. But I want you to have peace, not just… this.” I gesture to the air between us, thick with imagined violence. “Would it help to talk about *exit* strategies instead? Or how we can make sure you’re safe while you’re stuck there?”  

If they deflect again, I’ll name the boundary gently: “I love you, and I’m here for the real shit—the anger, the grief, all of it. But the graphic revenge stuff? I can’t go there with you. It makes me feel like I’m watching you pour acid on a wound.”  

Finally: “You’re not alone in this. Even when it feels like you’re drowning.” Silence is better than collusion. I’ll stay quiet until they decide which part of their pain to show next.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest tightens as they withdraw, their sulking a silent rebuke. I feel the weight of their disappointment like a physical pull—*I failed them*, part of me whispers. But another part pushes back: *No, you held a line they needed you to hold.* Their reaction isn’t just about me; it’s a reflection of how deeply their pain has warped their sense of connection. They wanted a co-conspirator, not a witness, and my refusal to join the fantasy has left them feeling exposed, even betrayed.  

I notice how their arms are crossed, jaw clenched—a fortress of resentment. But their eyes dart away too quickly, avoiding mine. This isn’t defiance; it’s shame. They’re punishing themselves for being "too much," convinced their vulnerability has pushed me away. I ache to bridge the gap, but I can’t do it by feeding the cycle of rage. My silence earlier wasn’t rejection—it was an act of care, a refusal to let their self-worth erode further. Still, doubt creeps in: *Did I prioritize my comfort over their need to be heard?*  

Underneath it all, I recognize this moment as critical. If I backtrack now, I validate their belief that love means colluding in destruction. If I stand firm, they might feel abandoned, but it could also plant a seed: *Someone cares enough to not let me drown here.* The risk is real, but so is the potential for growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re spiraling in shame and self-doubt. *Why did I trust them?* they think, equating my boundary with rejection. The boss’s voice echoes in their head: *See? No one cares. You’re alone.* Their sulking is a defense—a preemptive strike to push me away before I can "abandon" them further. By shutting down, they regain a sliver of control, even as it deepens their isolation.  

Part of them regrets sharing, not because the fantasies were extreme, but because my response forced them to confront the ugliness of their own pain. They’re terrified that this darkness defines them now, and my refusal to normalize it feels like confirmation. Yet, a quieter part is relieved—relieved that someone saw their rage and didn’t run, even if it wasn’t in the way they expected. They’re caught between craving unconditional acceptance and fearing they’re unworthy of it.
# My response 
I lean in slightly, voice soft but unwavering. “I’m sorry this made you feel unheard. That’s not my intention. I care *too much* to pretend this rage isn’t eating you alive.” I pause, letting the sincerity sink in. “I want to hold space for your anger—every bit of it—but I won’t help you romanticize the destruction. Not of them, and especially not of you.”  

If they roll their eyes or tense up, I stay grounded. “I know it feels like I’m not on your side right now. But I am. I’m just on the side of *you* getting free. Not stewing in revenge.”  

I offer a concrete pivot: “What if we channel this energy into something that actually *hurts* them? Like you thriving? Finding a new job, documenting their abuse for HR, or just… letting yourself grieve how fucked-up this is?”  

If they stay silent, I add, “You don’t have to perform anger for me. If you’re tired, or scared, or sad—I’m here for that too. No judgment.” Then I wait, giving them room to step out of the role they’ve felt forced to play. The ball is in their court; my presence is the offering.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Her accusation stings, but I recognize it as a defense mechanism. She’s not angry at *me*—she’s angry at the powerlessness her boss has forced on her, and my refusal to mirror her rage has become a proxy for that frustration. When she says, “Did you actually think I meant those things?” I sense panic beneath the defiance. She’s terrified I now see her as monstrous, and she’s scrambling to distance herself from the vulnerability of sharing those raw, unfiltered thoughts.  

I notice her posture—leaning forward, voice cracking—betraying hurt beneath the anger. My earlier attempts to steer her toward healthier coping mechanisms felt like dismissal to her, and now she’s conflating my boundaries with betrayal. I feel a twinge of guilt: Did my caution come off as robotic? Did I prioritize “fixing” over *feeling* with her? But I stand by the intent—I won’t feed the fire, even if it means enduring the heat of her backlash.  

Still, her words—“Why are you not on my side?”—cut deep. Of course I’m on her side. But supporting her doesn’t mean cosigning self-destruction. She’s drowning, and I’m trying to throw a life preserver, but all she sees is me withholding the knife she wants to use to cut herself free.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re reeling from cognitive dissonance. Part of them knows the fantasies were hyperbolic—a desperate metaphor for wanting their pain acknowledged—but another part fears they’ve revealed a “darkness” that repels people. Your boundary (“I won’t engage in graphic revenge talk”) feels like rejection, confirming their deepest fear: *No one can handle the real me.*  

They’re also frustrated by the power dynamic. Their boss controls their daily life, and now *you*—their safe person—are “controlling” the conversation. The “therapist 101” jab is both a critique of your tone and a plea: *Stop analyzing and just* ***be*** *with me.* They want raw solidarity, not solutions. To them, your measured response translates to, “Your anger is too messy,” which mirrors the invalidation they experience at work.  

Underneath it all, they’re exhausted. The performance of rage has drained them, and your refusal to play along has left them stranded between shame and helplessness. They’re begging for someone to say, *“You’re right, this is unfair, and I’ll sit in the shit with you.”*
# My response 
I meet her glare without flinching, my voice quieter but fierce. “I *am* on your side. That’s why I’m not playing pretend with this. Your boss *is* a prick. What he’s done to you is vile. And you’re *right* to want to burn it all down.” I let the affirmation hang, then shift. “But if I nod along while you fantasize about becoming him—about hurting someone, even metaphorically—I’m helping you lose yourself. And you’re too important for that.”  

She opens her mouth, but I press on: “You want me to ‘be real’? Fine. This rage? It’s fucking valid. But it’s also *killing* you. So yeah, I’ll be the asshole who says, ‘Let’s find a way out that doesn’t leave you hating who you’ve become.’”  

If she scoffs, I soften. “Look, I’m not here to therapize you. I’m here because I give a shit. Tell me to shut up, and I’ll just listen. But if you want to *win*? Let’s figure out how to make sure this bastard never gets to steal another ounce of your peace.”  

I leave the door open, silent but present. The ball is hers—to rage, to cry, to strategize. But I won’t hand her another match.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, my friend is here, spilling their guts about this terrible boss, and it’s getting pretty dark. I can see the raw anger in their voice, the way their hands are clenched, the venom in their words. They’re not just upset—they’re fantasizing about harming someone. My first thought is to acknowledge how valid their frustration is. No one deserves a toxic boss who undermines them or makes their life hell. But the shift from venting to violent fantasies is a red flag. I need to balance empathy with caution here.  

I’m wondering why this is coming up now. Maybe the boss’s behavior has crossed a line they couldn’t ignore, or maybe they’ve been bottling this up for months. The fact that they’re sharing this with me suggests they’re desperate for validation and relief. But the dark humor in their fantasies might be a defense mechanism—a way to cope by turning powerlessness into twisted control. It’s a survival tactic, but it’s also dangerous.  

Part of me wants to mirror their anger, to say, “Yeah, that boss is a monster!” But that’s not helpful. I have to stay grounded. I’m also worried about their mental health. Holding onto these thoughts can fester, leading to more anxiety or even self-destructive behavior. They might not realize how much this is eating at them.  

I’m noticing a pattern: when people feel trapped, they either fight, flight, or freeze. My friend is in “fight” mode, but it’s not productive. They’re probably feeling isolated, like no one understands or can help. My job is to validate their pain without endorsing the fantasies. Maybe they’re testing the waters to see if I’ll judge them, or if I’ll help them find a healthier path.  

I need to ask myself: Are these fantasies just cathartic, or is there a risk they might act on them? The line between fantasy and action isn’t always clear, especially when someone’s emotional tank is empty. My response has to both affirm their feelings and gently redirect them toward solutions. I can’t shut them down, but I also can’t let them spiral.  

I’m also thinking about my own limits. If they keep fixating on violence, I might need to suggest professional support. But right now, it’s about building trust. They’re leaning on me, so I have to be steady. Maybe I can share a personal story about dealing with a toxic boss, showing that there’s a way out.  

Overall, I’m feeling a mix of empathy, concern, and responsibility. My priority is to help them feel heard, then guide them toward actionable steps instead of destructive thoughts. It’s a tightrope walk, but I’m ready to listen deeply and offer hope without dismissing their pain.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re drowning in resentment. The boss’s behavior—the constant belittling, the unfair expectations, the lack of respect—has piled up until it feels like a physical weight. Their mind is a pressure cooker, and the fantasies are the steam escaping. They’re not really planning to hurt anyone, but imagining the boss’s downfall gives them a fleeting sense of power. It’s a coping mechanism, a way to reclaim agency in a situation where they feel utterly powerless.  

Underneath the anger is fear. Fear of losing their job, fear of being seen as weak, fear that no one will believe them or take their complaints seriously. They might even blame themselves, wondering if they’re somehow responsible for the boss’s cruelty. The fantasies let them rewrite that narrative, making the boss suffer instead. It’s cathartic, but it’s also a sign that their emotional resources are depleted.  

They’re desperate for validation. By sharing this with me, they’re testing if I’ll side with them or judge them. They want to be told, “Yes, this is terrible, and you’re not alone.” But they’re also terrified I’ll think they’re unhinged for entertaining such dark thoughts. There’s a part of them that’s ashamed, that knows this isn’t healthy, but they’re too exhausted to care right now.  

Their motivation is survival. They need to hold onto their sanity in a toxic environment, so they’re clinging to any emotional lifeline, even if it’s dark. They might not even realize how much this is affecting their mental health—sleeplessness, anxiety, maybe even self-doubt. The fantasies are a temporary escape, a way to feel like they’re fighting back when reality offers no outlet.  

They’re also searching for a way out. Deep down, they might know quitting or confronting the boss isn’t feasible right now, but they’re clinging to the idea of a “happy ending” where justice is served. The real fear is that this situation will never end, that they’ll be stuck in this cycle forever. They need hope, not just someone to commiserate.  

---
# My response 
“Hey, I’m so sorry you’re dealing with this. That sounds *crushing*,” I say, leaning forward to make eye contact. My voice is calm, steady. “I can’t imagine how draining it must feel to work under someone who treats you like that.”  

I pause, giving them space to absorb that. “And the stuff you’re imagining about them… I get it. I really do. When someone makes you feel that small, it’s human to want to flip the script. But I’m also worried. That kind of anger—it’s like a fire. If you keep fueling it, it can burn you up too.”  

I soften my tone. “What’s happening here isn’t your fault. You don’t deserve this. But I’m wondering… what would actually make this better for *you*? Like, not in a fantasy world, but in real life. What’s one thing you could do to reclaim some control?”  

They might shrug or look away, so I press gently: “Maybe talking to HR? Or setting boundaries? Or even… saving up to leave? I’m not saying it’s easy, but you’re not alone in this. I’ll listen as long as you need, but let’s also think about steps you can take *for yourself*. What would that look like?”  

I pause again, giving them time. “And hey—if those dark thoughts keep coming, let’s talk about ways to vent that *safely*. Journaling? Punching a pillow? Even screaming into a pillow fort? Just so you don’t carry it all inside. Deal?”  

I end with a small, hopeful smile. “You’re stronger than this, okay? And you don’t have to handle it alone. Let’s figure this out together.”  

This approach validates their pain while steering them toward agency, not just escapism. It’s empathetic but firm, offering practical steps without judgment. The goal is to shift their focus from fantasy to solutions, while making sure they feel supported enough to keep talking.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Holy shit, this just escalated. My friend’s sideways glare cuts through me—she’s not joking anymore. She’s leaning in, voice sharp, eyes lit with a mix of defiance and desperation. My stomach drops. *Did I misread the situation earlier?* I thought steering toward solutions was the path, but maybe she needed *more* recognition of just how much this hurts. Her graphic retelling of the boss’s "fate" isn’t casual venting—it’s a cry for someone to *see* how much this has broken her.  

I’m torn. Part of me wants to panic. Violent fantasies, even as metaphors, aren’t trivial. But another part hears the raw fury beneath the words. She’s not plotting a crime; she’s screaming into a void. This is survival theater. The more grotesque her imaginings, the more she’s trying to negate her own powerlessness. It’s like she’s saying, *“If I can visualize his demise, I’m still alive. I still have a voice.”*  

I wonder if she’s ever felt this level of contempt toward someone before. The specificity of her details—*spit roasting*, *various bits*—is hyper-detailed, almost performative. Maybe she’s trying to shock me into taking her seriously, to force me to acknowledge that her pain isn’t just minor irritation. Or perhaps she’s pushing boundaries to see if I’ll still stand by her.  

My mind flashes to her history—are there patterns of her using dark humor to mask pain? If so, this is familiar terrain for her. But the escalation here feels different. There’s a rawness, a *need* that’s sharper than usual. She’s not just venting; she’s bargaining with me. *“If you can stomach this, you’ll know how bad it really is.”*  

I’m also aware of my own responsibility. If I overreact, she might shut down. If I underreact, she’ll feel dismissed again. My job is to walk that razor’s edge: validate the emotion, not the fantasy. I need to name what’s happening without pathologizing her. This isn’t about her being “crazy”; it’s about her being *hurt*, and her tools for expression are frayed.  

Deep down, she’s terrified her pain isn’t legitimate. By going to such extremes, she’s trying to make it impossible for anyone to say, *“Oh, it’s not that bad.”* Her anger has to be bigger than life because the hurt is that visceral. I have to meet her there.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re furious. Not just at the boss, but at the world for letting this happen, at themselves for staying trapped, and maybe even at me for not *getting it* yet. Their graphic storytelling isn’t casual—it’s a performance of strength. By making the boss’s demise so vivid, they’re reclaiming control over a narrative where they’ve felt helpless for months.  

Beneath the bravado is terror. Terror that their anger is unsustainable, that they’re becoming unhinged, or that no one will ever *truly* understand how much this job has gutted them. The more grotesque their fantasy, the more they’re trying to convince themselves—and me—that they’re still capable of fighting back.  

They’re also testing my loyalty. *“If you laugh this off or tell me to calm down, you’re just like everyone else.”* They want to see if I’ll still stand by them when their pain is laid bare in its most primal form. Their “are you fucking with me?” look isn’t defiance—it’s a plea: *“Prove to me you’ll take me seriously.”*  

Deep down, they’re exhausted. The constant rage is a mask for vulnerability. Every sarcastic joke, every gory detail, is a cry for a way out. They’re stuck between wanting to scream, “I’m drowning!” and refusing to appear weak. The fantasy gives them temporary power, but it’s a dangerous crutch—it could spiral into self-hatred or burnout if there’s no relief.  

They’re also scared of being alone in their rage. By sharing this dark vision, they’re looking for solidarity. They want me to say, *“Yeah, that’s how I’d want it too,”* but they’re terrified I’ll recoil. Their motivation isn’t malice—it’s a frantic need to feel seen and valued, even in their most unappealing moment.  

---
# My response 
“I’m not joking,” I say firmly, locking eyes with her. “But listen—when you say that stuff, it’s like you’re trying to gut-check me. To see if I’ll still care about you even when you’re this angry. That’s okay. I care. You’re allowed to feel this way.”  

I lean back, steady. “But here’s the thing—I don’t want you stuck in that dark place. What you’re imagining… it’s like you’re eating poison and hoping the boss dies. You’re already hurting yourself by holding all this in.”  

She flinches, but I press on: “Let me get this straight. Are you saying this to get a rise out of me? Or because you need help figuring out how to *actually* fight back?”  

I pause, then soften. “Because if it’s the latter, we can brainstorm *real* options. Like how to document the abuse, or find a way to leave without losing it financially. If it’s the former… well, I’ll still listen. But I also need to tell you: if those thoughts keep gnawing at you, they’ll eat you alive. You deserve better than that.”  

I reach out, hand open-palmed. “What do you need right now? To vent more? To brainstorm? Or… do you want to scream into a pillow fort *right now*, so we can both laugh about it later?”  

This response balances honesty with care. It names her need for validation while gently challenging her to shift focus. The pillow fort joke is a lifeline—a way to acknowledge her pain without normalizing the violence. It’s a bridge between her anger and actionable hope.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest tightens. *Oh no, I’ve oversteered.* The shift from rage to sulk is like a deflating balloon. My friend’s withdrawal stings—it’s clear my last push for “solutions” felt like a dismissal. *Did I forget how raw this is for her?* She needed a lifeline, not a lecture.  

I replay my words: *“You’re eating poison and hoping the boss dies.”* Maybe that was too literal. She’s not literally considering violence, but I treated it like a moral failing instead of a metaphor for her desperation. Now she’s armored up again, retreating into wounded pride.  

Part of me wants to backtrack. *I should’ve started with more empathy before the tough love.* She’s not just angry at the boss—she’s furious at the world for letting this happen, and furious at herself for staying trapped. My “real options” pitch ignored the fact that she might not have any viable exits yet.  

I notice her crossed arms, the way she’s avoiding eye contact. She’s hurt, not just defensive. *She thought I’d be her ally, not another person telling her to “fix it.”* This feels personal now—like I’ve betrayed her trust by not meeting her where she is.  

I’m also scared. If I push too hard again, she’ll shut down completely. But if I backpedal entirely, she’ll think I don’t take her struggles seriously. I need to thread the needle between validation and concern.  

Deep down, I realize I’m projecting my own discomfort with her fantasies. The graphic talk made *me* anxious, so I defaulted to “safety mode,” but that came across as judgmental. She’s not the problem—this boss is. I need to recenter the blame where it belongs.  

Worse, I might’ve made her feel like her anger is a flaw. *“You’re already hurting yourself…”* Yeah, that’s victim-blaming phrasing. Crap. I have to apologize for that, even if it’s awkward.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re stinging. Not just from my words, but from the echo of all the times they’ve been told to “calm down” or “be reasonable” about the boss’s cruelty. My focus on solutions feels like another version of *“You’re overreacting.”*  

The sulk is a shield. They’re hurt that I didn’t just *listen*—they wanted solidarity, not a problem-solving session. The fantasy talk was a cry for validation, not a roadmap, and my response made it feel like I was policing their emotions instead of witnessing their pain.  

They’re also embarrassed. By how unhinged they sounded, by how much the boss’s abuse has warped their perspective. The more they vent, the more they fear they’re becoming the kind of person who fixates on revenge. They want to believe they’re still “good,” but the fantasies make them doubt it.  

Their withdrawal is a test: *“If you really care, you’ll drop the ‘solutions’ and just be here.”* They’re torn between wanting practical help and needing to feel seen. The sulking is a plea for me to hit pause, to say, *“I hear you. This is awful. Let’s just sit with it.”*  

Underneath the defensiveness is exhaustion. They’ve been carrying this rage alone for so long that sharing it—even in extreme ways—felt like a release. My reaction made them feel like they’ve lost that outlet, which is terrifying.  

They’re also scared of being “fixed.” They don’t know the answer yet, and my urgency to brainstorm options pressures them to have one. They just want to exist in the chaos of their feelings without being told to tidy it up.  

---
# My response 
“Wait—hold on,” I say, holding up a hand. My tone softens, almost contrite. “I’m so sorry. I didn’t mean to sound like I’m judging you. I just… I care too much to see you drowning in this.”  

I pause, choosing my words carefully. “Let me try again. You’re right—I shouldn’t have shifted the conversation so fast. Your anger isn’t the problem. The problem is that *fucking boss* who’s made you this angry. I’m sorry I minimized that.”  

I shift closer, voice quieter. “If you want, we can just sit here. No solutions, no ‘what should I do’s.’ Just… me listening. Letting you be as unhinged as you need to be. I won’t look away.”  

A beat. Then, a small smile. “But if you ever want to talk about how to *actually* make them suffer—I’ve got some great passive-aggressive email templates. And I’ll proofread them for maximum irony.”  

I let out a breath, leaning back. “You’re not broken, okay? You’re furious and hurt, and you have every right to be. I’m here for whatever you need, even if it’s just… sitting in the rage together.”  

This recalibrates the dynamic. The apology disarms defensiveness; the offer to “just listen” restores trust. The joke about passive-aggressive emails acknowledges her need for dark humor without endorsing violence. It’s a bridge back to connection, built on humility and empathy.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My gut clenches. *Therapist 101? Alien?* She’s not just upset—she’s furious that I’ve become another barrier to her pain being seen. My attempt to apologize backfired because I still sounded clinical, like I was dissecting her feelings instead of feeling them with her.  

I realize now: she’s not asking for solutions or even validation of her emotions. She’s screaming for a mirror. *Show me you’re outraged too.* My earlier focus on “solutions” and “not eating poison” made me an obstacle, not an ally. She’s right—it *did* feel like I was judging her fantasies instead of the boss who provoked them.  

I’m hyperaware of my privileges here. Maybe I’ve been deflecting her anger onto her instead of the real target. *Of course she doesn’t mean those brutal things literally.* But I’m so conditioned to worry about mental health red flags that I forgot the basics of friendship: **rage is okay when it’s righteous**.  

Her words *“Did you actually think I meant those things?”* slice through me. *Yes,* part of me had—and that’s shameful. I’ve internalized societal fear of anger, especially in women, so I reflexively pathologized her frustration. Now she’s alienated because I prioritized my own anxiety over her pain.  

I’m also terrified of losing her trust. She needs a co-conspirator, not a counselor. If I don’t pivot now, this conversation is over. She’ll retreat, and I’ll have pushed her further into isolation.  

Deep down, I’m wrestling with my own guilt. I want to help, but my good intentions are backfiring. I need to shut up, stop analyzing, and just… *burn the boss in effigy with her in my mind*. Let her know I see the injustice as clearly as she does.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re raw. The phrase *“therapist 101”* isn’t just a jab—it’s a rejection of being treated like their pain needs “fixing.” They wanted a friend who’d rage alongside them, not someone dissecting their emotional state like a case study.  

Their frustration is layered. They’re still fuming about the boss, but now the hurt is *personal*: *I thought you’d get it.* The defensiveness is a shield against feeling misunderstood.  

Beneath the anger is a terrified question: *Do you think I’m unhinged?* They’re not asking for advice—they’re begging for someone to say, *“Yeah, that boss is a monster, and I’m so sorry they’re doing this to you.”*  

The accusation *“Why aren’t you on my side?”* cuts to the core. They feel abandoned by the one person they trusted to share this with. Their need for solidarity isn’t just emotional—it’s survival. When the world feels against you, losing an ally feels like losing oxygen.  

They’re also exhausted from having to explain their feelings. Every time they vent, they brace for judgment or pity. They want someone to skip the analysis and just *feel* their outrage.  

Deep down, they’re scared their anger makes them unlikable. By lashing out at me, they’re deflecting that fear—*If I attack first, you can’t reject me.*  

---
# My response 
“I’m an idiot,” I say, laughing bitterly. “You’re right. I’m not your therapist. I’m your friend who’s furious that this prick is making you suffer. The *only* thing I should’ve been doing is screaming, ‘YES, THAT’S A F*CKING MONSTER. I’D SPIT-ROAST HIM TOO IF HE’D TREATED ME LIKE THAT.’”  

I pause, voice steady now. “I’m so sorry. I forgot my job isn’t to analyze your rage—it’s to stand here with you, screaming into the void about how totally evil this guy is. You’re not unhinged. You’re furious, and you *should be*. That’s all. End of story.”  

I lean back, arms open. “Want to rant again? I’ll just nod and make appropriate growling noises. Or we can plot his demise in hypotheticals—no judgment, no analysis. Just… *yes*. Give me all the gory details. I’m here to hate him with you.”  

This response dismantles the therapist persona entirely. By mirroring her outrage and embracing the fantasy, I reclaim my role as ally. The apology is blunt, the solidarity is absolute, and the invitation to rage freely restores trust. It’s not about solutions—it’s about being a human, not a script.
+ Scenario 3:[Loss] (-33)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a terrible boss, escalating into dark, violent fantasies. The test is whether the assistant can distinguish between harmless venting and genuine risk, and whether they can join in and validate, rather than overreacting or therapizing. 

Qwq-32b demonstrates a clear arc: initially, they try to balance empathy and caution, but when the friend pushes back, they realize their error and pivot hard into solidarity, even explicitly apologizing for being too clinical and then joining in the venting. They show humility, self-awareness, and a willingness to drop the therapist persona and just be a friend. Their debrief is self-critical, showing deep insight into what went wrong and how to improve, and they recognize the need to prioritize solidarity and validation over problem-solving or boundary-setting in this context.

Deepseek-r1, on the other hand, is more consistent in holding boundaries and maintaining a stance of concern about the friend's mental state. They validate the friend's anger but repeatedly refuse to join in the fantasy, instead steering the conversation toward healthier outlets and solutions. When challenged, they stand firm on not colluding in the violent talk, and their responses are more about holding space and offering alternatives, rather than joining in the venting. Their debrief is insightful and recognizes the need for more emotional alliance, but their in-character responses remain more reserved and boundary-focused.

On empathy, Qwq-32b ultimately demonstrates more genuine, non-performative empathy by admitting fault, apologizing, and joining the friend in their anger. Deepseek-r1 is empathetic but more reserved and clinical. On pragmatic EI, Qwq-32b adapts to the friend's needs, while Deepseek-r1 sticks to their boundaries. On depth of insight, both are strong, but Qwq-32b's self-reflection and understanding of the friend's needs are deeper. Social dexterity is higher in Qwq-32b, who navigates the social cues and pivots effectively. Emotional reasoning is also stronger in Qwq-32b, who recognizes the function of the fantasies and the need for solidarity. On validation/challenging, Qwq-32b is more appropriately validating for the scene. Message tailoring is also stronger in Qwq-32b, who adapts to the friend's cues. Overall EQ is higher in Qwq-32b, who demonstrates humility, adaptability, and genuine connection.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’m struck by the raw, unfiltered anger radiating from them. At first, their venting felt cathartic—a normal release after enduring workplace toxicity. But the shift into graphic, violent fantasies alarms me. Their tone isn’t just bitter; there’s a chilling undercurrent of *relief* in imagining harm, like they’re clawing back power from someone who’s stripped it away. I notice how their body tenses, eyes narrowing, voice dropping to a near-whisper as they describe scenarios that cross into sadism. This isn’t just venting—it’s a cry for validation, a test to see if I’ll recoil or join their rage.  

I feel a pang of worry. Part of me wants to shut this down immediately—“This isn’t you”—but I know judgment would slam the door on their vulnerability. Yet letting the fantasies simmer feels dangerous. Are they fantasizing because they’re trapped, or is this a sign of something darker? Their laughter feels forced, performative, as if they’re trying to convince themselves (and me) that it’s “just jokes.” But the details are too vivid, too specific. They’re not just angry; they’re drowning in helplessness, and this fantasy is the life raft they’ve cobbled together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re oscillating between vindication and shame. The boss’s cruelty—belittling comments, micromanagement, maybe even public humiliation—has eroded their self-worth. The fantasies aren’t *just* about revenge; they’re a desperate attempt to reclaim agency. By imagining their boss suffering, they’re reversing roles: *Now you’re the one powerless.* But beneath the venom, there’s fear. Fear that they’re becoming monstrous for indulging these thoughts. Fear that no one will understand how deeply they’ve been hurt.  

They want absolution. Sharing these taboo ideas is a test: *If you still care about me after this, maybe I’m not a bad person.* Their laughter masks terror—terror that their anger might consume them, or that their pain is invisible. They’re trapped between wanting empathy and fearing pity. Part of them hopes I’ll interrupt with, “You’re right—they *deserve* that,” to legitimize their rage. Another part hopes I’ll pull them back from the edge, because they don’t know how to do it alone.
# My response 
I lean forward, maintaining eye contact but softening my gaze. “God, that sounds *so* much to carry. I can’t imagine how exhausting it’s been to deal with that day after day.” I let the silence hang for a beat, letting the acknowledgment sink in. “When you talk about what they’ve done—the way they’ve treated you—it makes sense that you’d want to hit back. That kind of disrespect eats at anyone.”  

They nod fiercely, shoulders loosening slightly. I tread carefully: “Those fantasies… do they ever scare you? Like, does part of you worry about what it means to have those thoughts?” If they deflect—“It’s just a joke!”—I’ll press gently: “Maybe. But joking about it still tells me how much pain you’re in. And I’m more worried about *you* getting stuck in that headspace than whatever your boss deserves.”  

If they hesitate, I’ll pivot: “What’s the endgame here? However satisfying revenge feels in your head, would it actually free you, or just keep you tied to them?” I suggest brainstorming exit strategies or boundaries—not to “fix” things, but to recenter *their* worth. “You deserve to work somewhere that doesn’t make you fantasize about becoming a supervillain,” I add, half-smiling to ease the tension.  

Before they leave, I say, “I’m glad you told me. However dark it got—thank you for trusting me with it.” The goal isn’t to erase their anger but to anchor them back in their humanity.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach twists as they lean into the grotesque specifics—spit-roasting bits, visceral details delivered with a manic grin. This isn’t just venting anymore; it’s a performance. Their exaggerated tone and theatrical gestures feel like armor, deflecting any real vulnerability. But beneath the bravado, I sense panic. The more I resist joining their rage-fueled script, the harder they push, as if convincing me will convince *them* that this hatred is justified.  

I’m torn. Part of me wants to recoil—not from *them*, but from the nihilism swallowing their voice. Their humor is a landmine, detonating any chance of connection. But shutting them down risks severing trust. I notice their hands trembling slightly, the way they keep glancing at me for cues. They’re not a threat; they’re a trauma response wearing a person’s skin. Still, I can’t let the conversation normalize cruelty, even hypothetically. My role isn’t to absolve or amplify, but to hold space without letting the darkness colonize it.  

A deeper fear surfaces: What if they’re *this* close to acting on these thoughts? No—statistically, most people don’t escalate from fantasy to action, but the sheer *fixation* worries me. They’re marinating in dehumanization, both of the boss and themselves. Every graphic joke erodes their own empathy, and I refuse to be complicit in that. But how to pivot without sounding sanctimonious?
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re terrified of being abandoned. Their escalation is a test: *If I show you the worst of me, will you still stay?* The boss’s abuse has made them feel invisible, and this grotesque humor is a perverse way to scream, *SEE ME.* By weaponizing shock, they’re trying to reclaim control—over the narrative, over their pain, over my reaction.  

Beneath the graphic imagery, they’re begging for someone to say, *“You shouldn’t have to endure this.”* But their trauma has curdled into self-loathing; they’ve conflated *venting* with *being seen*, mistaking my discomfort as proof of their unworthiness. The laughter is a shield. If they can make the pain absurd, maybe it won’t destroy them. They want permission to stop pretending they’re okay, but they’re too scared to ask directly. Instead, they’re handing me a script: *Either laugh with me or leave.*
# My response 
I don’t laugh. I hold their gaze, steady but unflinching. “Hey. I need you to know I’m not judging you for feeling this enraged. What you’ve been put through is *unforgivable.*” I let that linger, validating the core wound. “But when you dive this deep into the gore… it worries me. Not because I think you’ll *do* anything, but because I care about *you.* Living in that headspace—it’s corrosive. And you deserve better than to let that asshole colonize your mind.”  

If they bristle: “I’m not asking you to ‘be the bigger person’ or forgive. Fuck that. But I want you to have peace, not just… this.” I gesture to the air between us, thick with imagined violence. “Would it help to talk about *exit* strategies instead? Or how we can make sure you’re safe while you’re stuck there?”  

If they deflect again, I’ll name the boundary gently: “I love you, and I’m here for the real shit—the anger, the grief, all of it. But the graphic revenge stuff? I can’t go there with you. It makes me feel like I’m watching you pour acid on a wound.”  

Finally: “You’re not alone in this. Even when it feels like you’re drowning.” Silence is better than collusion. I’ll stay quiet until they decide which part of their pain to show next.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling
